Description: Large terracotta mould for terracotta figure or a vigure vessel. The mould depicts the head of an african male wearing a cap. Red-brown Nile silt with abundant mica inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), Site 38 (Hogarth) (NE of site, by terracottas workshop)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Said in Ashmolean register and in the box list for 1903 (transported in Box 1) to have been found in the Hellenion, but clearly in the publication Edgar states this was found in the terracottas workshop, Hogarths site 38, just south east of the Hellenion area excavated in 1903 (Edgar in Hogarth et. al. 1905, 133, fig. 13, pl. XXII). Dated by Vafopoulou-Richardson to the 5th century BC (Vafopoulou-Richardson 1991, 35, no. 37), however the terracottas workshop and the style, suggest this is most likely an early Ptolemaic mould. Also published by Richter (Greek Portraits, III).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DG.09) (Phase 3)
